awd_titl_txt: Development of Synthetically Versatile C-H Activation Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will focus on the development of broadly useful Pd- and Cu-catalyzed C-H activation/trifluoromethylation and C-H activation/halogenation reactions (including fluorination).  Despite recent progress on this front using classic cyclometalation, the discovery of analogous reactivity with synthetically useful substrates containing weakly coordinating functional groups remains a significant challenge.  Extensive experimental work will be performed to find solutions to such problems based upon well supported hypotheses.  In addition, the knowledge learned from the studies to establish new catalytic transformations and to probe the underlying reaction mechanisms will be applied to develop enantioselective C-H halogenation reactions.

With this award, the Chemical Synthesis program is supporting the research of Professor Jin-Quan Yu of the Department of Chemistry at The Scripps Research Institute.  Professor Yu's research efforts focus on the discovery and development of synthetically versatile C-H functionalization reactions.  These transformations represent environmentally benign methods for chemical synthesis in that they may drastically shorten synthetic sequences.  New technologies based on these reactions could have a substantial impact on synthetic planning and immediate practical applications in the pharmaceutical and agrochemical industries.  In addition, this project will provide excellent training to both graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.   It also involves outreach activities to high school students.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our project centers on the discovery and invention of new catalytic C–H activation reactions through which C–H bonds in molecules are replaced by a wide range of functional groups. These processes either improve the desired properties of drug molecules, agrochemicals, perfumes and materials, or reduce the costs of the syntheses of target molecules with significant industry importance. Guided by this goal, we obtained a new understanding of how C–H activation with metal catalysts occurs and applied this insight towards the development of C–H activation reactions utilizing abundant and cheap starting materials such as carboxylic acids, alcohols and amines. Consequently, we invented a number of new transformations by designing new catalytic systems. For example, our recently developed C–H borylation, trifluoromethylation and C–H phosphorylation reactions catalyzed by Pd catalysts are unprecedented. These new reactions allow for the introduction of a wider range of functional groups through C–H activation directly, thus expanding the scope of industrial applications of this rapidly rising new technology in organic synthesis. To apply these reactions to the asymmetric synthesis of biologically important chiral molecules, we have also developed a chiral ligand derived from readily available amino acids to accomplish the first example of enantioselective C–H iodination. This reaction provides a new method for the construction of chiral amines bearing iodides that can be readily converted to a wide range of medicinally important compounds. These newly developed reactions have drawn broad interests from synthetic chemists, computational chemists and medicinal chemists, as evidenced by the large number of international publications from other laboratories that pursue further studies or applications of our reactions. A number of reactions developed in our laboratory have already been used in pharmaceutical industry to accelerate drug discovery. Our research program has also trained five graduate students and five postdoctors during the past grant period.


Last Modified: 10/29/2014
Modified by: Jin-Quan Yu
